candidates.title: Did a KGB Agent Confirm That the Sex Pistols Were Backed by the USSR to Destabilize the West?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A KGB agent admitted that the Sex Pistols were financed by the USSR to destabilize Western democracy.
Rating:
False
About this rating
On 9 May 2017, Facebook page "The Church of PUNK" shared an article reporting that a KGB agent admitted the band the Sex Pistols were an operation backed by the former Soviet Union to destabilize Western democracy:
The April 2015 article reported that at the time it was published, a former KGB agent had just disclosed the punk rock plot:
Alexandrei Varennikovic Voloshin, a retired KGB agent, has admitted this week on National Russian Television (NTV) that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) was behind the creation of the 1970s punk scene and financed major punk bands such as the Sex Pistols, the Clash and the Ramones.
The USSR government at the time spent hundreds of millions of rubles on this covert operation destined to create utter chaos and pervert the Western youth to nihilist, anti-establishment and anti-american ideologies he explained in an hour long interview broadcast on national television.
There is no truth to this story; World News Daily Report states on its own disclaimer page that all of the content on the site is fictional:
WNDR assumes however all responsibility for the satirical nature of its articles and for the fictional nature of their content. All characters appearing in the articles in this website  even those based on real people  are entirely fictional and any resemblance between them and any persons, living, dead, or undead is purely a miracle.
candidates.description: A Facebook page for punk fans recirculated an old (and fake) story that the Sex Pistols were a KGB plot to foment dissent in the West.

Snopes.com, a reputable fact-checking website, rates this claim as false, citing the origin as a fictional story from World News Daily Report, a site known for satire.

The absence of any relevant entities in the image makes the caption's claim completely unsubstantiated from an image-based perspective. The confidence score of 0 reflects this complete lack of visual evidence supporting the caption. 

External Check: The external check leverages outside resources to verify the caption's claim.  It cites Snopes.com, a well-respected fact-checking website, which explicitly labels the claim as false. Snopes traces the origin of this claim to a known satirical news source, World News Daily Report, reinforcing the falsity of the statement.  The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong external evidence disproving the caption. 

Discrepancies and Conflict Analysis: There is no discrepancy between the internal and external checks. Both independently arrive at the same conclusion: the caption is false and completely out of context with the provided image.  The external check provides concrete evidence (Snopes fact-check) that strengthens the conclusion reached through the internal visual analysis. 

Entity Analysis:  The entities mentioned in the caption (KGB agent, Sex Pistols, Soviet operation, Western democracy) are not present, represented, or even hinted at in the image.  This absence further reinforces the out-of-context nature of the caption.

Conclusion:  The comprehensive assessment, combining both internal and external validations, overwhelmingly supports the conclusion that the caption is entirely out of context.  The high confidence score of 10 reflects the robust evidence from both image analysis and external fact-checking.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external checks independently and strongly confirm that the caption is false and completely unrelated to the image. The claim is debunked by Snopes.com and lacks any visual support within the image itself.
